hints_html:
Recall that the mth coefficient in a Taylor Polynomial is given by

\[\begin{aligned} c_m = \frac{f^{(m)}(a)}{m!}.\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
Recall that the ''m''th coefficient in a Taylor Polynomial is given by

:<math>
c_m = \frac{f^{(m)}(a)}{m!}.
</math>
question: 1 (m)
sols_html:
In general if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}p(x) = c_0 + c_1 (x-a) + c_2 (x-a)^2 + ... + c_n (x-a)^n\end{aligned}\]

is the nth degree Taylor polynomial to \(f(x)\) centred at \(x=a\) then the coefficient is

\[\begin{aligned} c_m = \frac{f^{(m)}(a)}{m!}.\end{aligned}\]

If

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f(x) = e^{2x+1}\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= 2 e^{2x+1}\\ f''(x) &= 4 e^{2x+1}\\ f'''(x) &= 8 e^{2x+1}.\end{aligned}\]

Since we are centering about \(0\),

\[\begin{aligned} c_3 = \frac{f'''(0)}{3!} = \frac{8e}{6}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
In general if 

:<math>
\displaystyle{}p(x) = c_0 + c_1 (x-a) + c_2 (x-a)^2 + ... + c_n (x-a)^n
</math>

is the nth degree Taylor polynomial to <math>f(x)</math> centred at <math>x=a</math> then the coefficient is

:<math>
c_m = \frac{f^{(m)}(a)}{m!}.
</math>

If

:<math>
\displaystyle{}f(x) = e^{2x+1}
</math>

then

:<math>
\begin{align}
f'(x) &= 2 e^{2x+1}\\
f''(x) &= 4 e^{2x+1}\\
f'''(x) &= 8 e^{2x+1}.
\end{align}
</math>

Since we are centering about <math>0</math>,

:<math>
c_3 = \frac{f'''(0)}{3!} = \frac{8e}{6}.
</math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}p_3(x)=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2+c_3x^3\end{aligned}\]

be the third degree Taylor polynomial for the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f(x)=\textrm{e}^{2x+1}\end{aligned}\]

at x=0. Determine the value of \(c_3\).
statement_raw:
Let

:<math>
\displaystyle{}p_3(x)=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2+c_3x^3
</math>

be the third degree Taylor polynomial for the function

:<math>
\displaystyle{}f(x)=\textrm{e}^{2x+1}
</math>

at x=0.  Determine the value of <math>c_3</math>.
